description:
Everyone knows the garden game where you have a tennis ball attached to a rope so that when you whack it, it spins around a central pole so that the other player can hit it back again. Well, this is the indoor equivalent. All made of plastic and a soft ball, you can recreate the garden game beautifully.

As usual with a new Aurora Skittle game, Don Adams (of Get Smart fame) is on the cover, but here he looks a little bored. Maybe he is thinking "I have done too many skittle games.......".

Snap Action Bowling is a cool game by Shelcore. The bowler's arm is spring loaded and shoots a ball down the alley with great speed. The balls, brown marbles, are painted with three finger holes! Attention to detail make this a very enjoyable game.

A marble maze game.

Each player tries to navigate through the maze, which has 50 holes along the route. Fall in a hole and your turn is over. The twist with this maze is that you have to turn it through 360 degrees to get to the end.

After the pre-decided time limit has run out, the winnere is the player who got furthest if nobody got to the end. Getting to the end first is an automatic win.

Find the longest link using 6 colors of gems or make the most links possible to win.

How to play:
1) Flip over and mix 84 Hetrix tiles thoroughly. Players get 5 tiles each.
2) Flip over and mix 12 link tiles thoroughly. Players get 1 tile each.
3) Everyone begins the game at the same time. Turn over the tiles and build a matrix. Do not let others see your link tile. This can be used only once in your own matrix.
4) 4 rounds are played with 5 tiles each round and points are tallied at the end of all 4 rounds.

Traditional Quoits game. The target has 12 hooks, worth points from 2 to 13. The rings provided are rubber.

The most points after several turns each, wins

Each player get a random character. One card is flipped over and depending on the card and your character the players have to react with actions (or non actions). Some cards reward the fastest and some have a penalty for the slowest.

A simple Moomin-themed dexterity game, where players use a contraption to lift a Moomintroll disc higher and higher, inserting new pieces in the bottom of the tower. When the tower topples, everybody but the player responsible scores a point. Play until you reach the target score.

In Accolade each player takes on the role of the Lord of a medieval household.  The players must guide four Squires on their journey around the board on their quest to become Knights and garner influence for their household.  During their journey, they will also be attempting to keep the rival households in check.  Can you be the most influential Lord and gain the ear of the King?  Only time will tell.

Inspired by classic games such as Parcheesi/Ludo and Checkers/Draughts, Accolade is an abstract game of chance and strategy, which has players maneuver their Squires around the exterior path of the board in an attempt to reach their home cathedral (similar to Parcheesi).  Once the Squire makes it to the cathedral, he receives his Accolade and is knighted.  This new Knight now reenters the board, now with the sole goal of interfering with your opponent's Squires and Knights.

The board is made up of a central hub and 4 spokes, which are assembled differently depending on the number of players (2-4), allowing for a scalable game that decreases the amount of dead time experienced in a 2 player game of Parcheesi/Ludo.  Though the board could also be used as an alternate Parcheesi board using those standard rules (and there is a bonus draughts board on the back of the main hub as well).

The main mechanic of the game is simple dice rolling for movement in a similar style to Parcheesi, but the pieces have more options on what they can do with those rolls.  Opposing pawns (Squires/Knights) interact with each other by Checking (landing on them, as in Parcheesi) or Capturing (jumping over, as in Checkers) them.  Pawns can attain a degree of safety by being in Castle spaces, or forming a Castle by doubling up 2 pawns of the same color.

Points (influence) are scored for removing opposing Squire / Knights and for any of your own Knights on the board (not in your home area).

The game ends once all remaining pawns are Knights, then the player with the most points (influence) gains the ear of the King and is considered the winner.

The game was created as an entry for TGC Classic Game Mashup Contest.

Objective: Try to protect all your mice - put them into a safe hideout.
'Kater Kralle' (cat Claw) is busy with hunting mice and tries to imprison them. Only those who can hide themselves below the turning 'cheese wheel' are safe.
The first player who can protect all his/her mice wins the game.  
Content:
1 'cheese wheel' (board)
18 mice 
1 'Kater Kralle' 
4 prisons
1 wooden die (with symbols)
1 rule sheet

Objective: Try to form as many valuable colour combinations as possible
Azuleo has its origin from the Portuguese word „azulejo“ for „tile“.
Starting the game a player draws/places two tiles (crosses) which determine the colour-combinations you can score. During your turn you should place a tile out of your personal supply (max. 2) which fits into. The allowed combination shows a square consisting of max. two colours. 
You may change the colour tiles for other combinations, too and you can also score points for placing blockade crosses where no colour cross can fit.

Taken from the Publisher's Website

It is a boardgame for 2 players that defy each other forming their team composed of 5 elements each one with different abilities of contrast/shot, with the aiming of score more goals than the adversary. Every player puts his players onto the field according to his tactical choices and makes the actions trying to get free from marking the adversary and to shoot at goal.

Content:
1 handbook with rules; 1 game board (the football field); 20 cardboard shapes  (the 2 teams); 20 little plastic bases; 6 cardboards balls; 1 ball (plastic pawn); 2 dice (1-6); 1 plus/minus dice (+/-).

Objective: try to understand the thoughts of the other players
 - collect as many (matching) chips as possible.
Within of many dragons dominated (illustrated) Europe (map) you see very nice & cute drawings all over the board.
The players try to be right with their guesses about the linkage of attributes and drawings.
Example:
The two adjectives 'enviable' and 'fiery' can be related to 
'Flamenco' in Spain or to a 'love couple' image in Denmark.
If you match the active player's decision you score (chips).

Objective:
Replay of the economical stuff learned on middle school
game ends after 90 min ==> winner: most points/money

Economic & educational game (simulation of a company producing
teenage furniture) 
Check - if pupils have learned economic stuff successfully 
 - moving/acting by turn -

players roll the die, move their meeples; if you land on a marked area draw a card:
cards have questions coming out from 
a. calculation (cash discount, credits, stocks...)
b. accounting (different business cases)
c. cost-benefit analysis
d. economic analysis / spreadsheets
solving these questions takes time, because most often you have
to find a problem-solving approach, subsequently to calculate getting correct result
collecting bonus points/money to get awarded

DKT, das kaufämnnische Talent, is an Austrian pendant for the well-known Monopoly. This version is very similar to »DKT dynamic«, but it has some party-elements.
As in DKT dynamic the goal is to pay back the starting money. The prices of the alpine regions change with the seasons. On two fields, all the players have to perform a task (depending on the season). The last one has to pay …

Hier wird in den alpinen Tourismus investiert. Die Spieler erstehen Grundstücke in den Alpen und versuchen sie durch den Ausbau mit Hütten und Hotels lukrativ zu machen, ihr Geld zu mehren und schuldenfrei zu werden. Sommer- und Wintertourismus erfordern unterschiedliche Aktivitäten und Touristenattraktionen.

Contents
1 Game Platform.
1 Contract Board.
1 Pack of Contract Cards
1 Pack of Box Office Journal Cards.
1 Pack of Publicity Cards.
1 Pack of Audience Cards.
2 Packs of Artists Cards.
Various Money Tokens.
6 Counter's.
16 Pegs.
2 Dice.
1 Set of Rules.

"Make the Headlines With the Stars of Your Own Choice - Every Player is an Impresario"

The objective is to Become a Successful Agent. Each Player is an agent and by shrewd handling of the stars they represent they will hope to accumulate money. It is a standard roll dice and move round the board. You get hired by stars (the cards feature real photos of popular British stars of the 50's) and you hope to find them work. Features Include - Audience Cards,Star Ratings Chart,Contracts, Publicity and Hit or Flop.
The first player to make £50,000 has proven to be successful and is the winner of the game.

Stars include - Dickie Valentine, James Arness, Tommy Trinder, Benny Hill, Lucille Ball, Petula Clark and many more.

D.o.D. - Dice or Date is a board game that can involve a minimum of 2 to a maximum of 6 players, in a world populated by Nerd trying to get an appointment with Amata, the most beautiful and proud girl of the City.
Help your Nerd collecting treasures to finally cross the three different dates Gate (Amata's family, his colleagues and her friends) that lead to the beautiful Beloved and her cold disdain for our protagonists.
Through a fully illustrated game board, consulting and moving pieces of plexiglass, players can choose between 6 different Nerd (specialists in many subjects: horror, science fiction, comics, TV series, Internet and video games, fantasy) willing to challenge themselves through direct competitions, Events , crossroads of the Devil, Retail and Fortress of Solitude.

Starting with $25,000 and a studio car, players traverse the gameboard with script in hand with the goal of meeting the requirements to complete their movies. Players roll and move with the usual assortment of chance elements found in board games such as these, but they are free trade and barter at will. The first to complete one’s assigned script requirements is the winner.

You play a mastermind, sending your agents to gather control over matters momentous and sinister. The threads come together to put a person in a place at a time. It is by such capers that you will prove your superlative … mastermindery? You are not sure that's a word, but your genius cannot be contained by the bounds of vocabulary.

In this auction game, players bid a number of agents that they will commit to a task. The high bidder takes a card. Agents committed to taking the card eventually return. If there is a tie in the initial auction, players bid delay - an extra amount of time they are willing to wait before getting their agents back.

This is one of the games included in The Revised and Expanded Decktet Book.

Contents
1 3D Playing Board(Battle Ground).
2 Spring Loading Guns.
10 Figure's.
2 Bullets.
Rules Are Printed on Inner Box Lid.
'The Blues and the Greys'.
Ambush is a Game of Strategy and Accurate Shooting. The object is to get your men to the enemy gun position to win the game.
The game is played on a three dimensional board. The soldiers need the hills to protect them from enemy fire, which is real enough, as you get to fire bullets at the advancing soldiers with your spring-loaded gun.

The winner is the first to reach the enemy's gun position.

Contents
1 Game Board.
4 Cars.
16 Shops(4 Green/12 Red).
8 Traffic Lights.
8 Pedestrians.
4 One Way Street Arrows.
16 Treasury Notes(Two Denominations).
1 Pack of Traffic Control Cards. 
8 Conical Obstruction Pieces.
1 Set of Rules.

Each player sets out from their home garage on a shopping expedition by car. They first head for the Bank to draw money sufficient to cover their purchases (Note: No cash machines or credit cards 55 years ago). Then the players proceed to the various shops to spend the money. Finally, the players return to the Bank to draw money to take home.

The first player having made the required value of purchases and arrived back in their garage with the correct amount of money, wins the game.

Look out for traffic lights, pedestrians, one way streets and obstructions as you shop.

Pebble Rebel is a strategy game for two players. Each player has different goals and different ways of playing, but still get in each other's way.

If Pebble gets four stones of the same color in a row, horizontally or vertically, she wins. (Diagonal four-in-a-row does not count.)
If Rebel fills up the whole board, he wins.

Contents 
4 Boxes of Puzzle Pieces.
Central Pool Puzzle Pieces.
1 Set of Rules.

"A game of skill and chance that combines the fascination of Jig-Saw construction with the thrill of a race game." says the box and going on to say "Not just an ordinary Jig-Saw, but an entirely new idea that leaves the result of the race a speculation to the last piece."

Each player has one of the colour coded boxes of pieces.
There is also a central pool of pieces for the water jump.
Players begin their puzzles - This forms part of their race track. Once their piece's are used up,the water jump is made, using pieces from the centre pool. The winner is the first one to complete their track the fastest (including the water jump).

The rules suggest that counters may be used For side stakes if required.

Contents
2 Clamps.
2 Wooden Poles.
1 Ball.
7 Wood Skittles

Indoor game that lends itself to skittle games where you swing round a ball on a string, trying to knock down the skittles as it sweeps by. In England this type of game was always known as Bar Skittles.

Skittle-Tennis has a ball on a string but the string is longer and must be hit with a bat rather than out of the hand.

The skittles are rated for different point values. Obviously, you should try to knock over the higher scoring ones. The first player to score 100 points is the winner.

From the rules "An interesting game that can produce an excellent method of training the eye for both Table Tennis and Tennis.

There are some game variants in the rules.

Contents
1 Poolette Wheel.
2 Metal Ballbearings.
1 Board with Colours and Numbers.
1 Board for Chips.
1 Set of Rules.

This game consists of a wheel similar to a Roulette wheel, a board which holds the bank's 'money', a stake board, a couple of ball bearing and a box of counters (Emu, made in England). The game was made by R. Cox Products Ltd. of Worcester but there's nothing to say on the rules when it was made. The picture on the lid shows a very posh gentleman croupier.

The game is all about betting. One player acts as the banker (until Pass Bank is decided on the wheel and then the bank passes to the left).Players place their bets on any number of colours.
Also the Winning Division Which Denotes - the Odds to Be Paid Out.

Some of the Divisions Are:
ODDS(Stakes Paid Out at Rate Indicated on Winning Colour).
POOLETTE(All Stakes Go Into a Pool Including Winning Colour).
BANKER TAKES POOL(Banker Takes All Stakes on Board and Pool).
WINNERS TAKE POOL(Stakes Divided Plus Any Pool).
DOUBLE STAKES RE-RACE(All Stakes on Board Doubled - Spin Again).

This game has been published by dV Giochi as a reward for winning the 2010/2011 edition of the Gioco Inedito – Best Unpublished game contest. Powered by Lucca comics & Games and dV Giochi, the contest aims to identify the best new card game design from all prototypes received and to reward it by publishing the game in a fully professional and high-quality format, overseen directly by dV Giochi. All prototypes submitted must conform to the technical and style requirements, fixed components and a given theme which changes every year. Everybody can join the contest and this is a great opportunity for emerging game designers to see their idea published. For more information:
giocoinedito@luccacomicsandgames.com
www.luccacomicsandgames.com

In The Gang, players try to play cards to capture gang members – with both gangs at risk of being captured. To set up each of the three cities in the game, draw five gangster cards at random, then place them in a row in numerical order (with a range of 1-80). Even and odd cards belong to different gangs and are color-coded. Each player has a hand of four gangster cards and a random special action card.

On a turn, each player chooses one gangster and one city card/one special card, then they reveal them simultaneously. Players place cards in ascending order from lowest to highest. If a gangster was played with a city card, it's placed in that city in the proper numerical spot; if it was played with a special card, it can be placed in any city, with the special card being placed in the same city before or after the gangster. If the card you placed is one of two gangsters surrounding at least two gangsters of the other color, then you capture the surrounded gangsters and remove them from play. Special cards let you play on the end of a row, switch a gangster from even to odd (or vice versa), or move a gangster from one row to another.

After four rounds, players discard their special card (if it hasn't been played), then receive a new hand of four gangsters and a special card. Any rows with fewer than five cards are filled to five cards. The game continues until not enough cards remain to fill players' hands and the rows; when this happens, the game ends immediately and players count the revolvers on the gangsters they've captured. The player with the high score wins.

The players draw cards, stand one behind the other and put one hand on the person in front as shown in the cards they drew. The first player picks up the wooden baton and ball standing in front of him/her and carefully passes it on to the next player. If the baton and ball arrive at the last player everyone has won that round of the game.

Fun and skill are the most important here. Pipifax develops body awareness, balance and team spirit and trains the recognition of different positions.

Contents
1 Wooden Base.
2 Tree Trunk Sections.
1 Palm Leaf Connector Unit.
4 Green Palm Leaves.
1 Chimpanzee.
12 Monkeys (3 of each in 4 colours).
2 Dice.
Rules (printed inside the box lid).

A race game where you are racing up the plastic palm tree instead of around a board. Each player has an equal share of the monkeys. Dice are thrown to climb (each notch is four spaces apart).

The monkeys want to get to the fruit at the top of the tree - therefore the objective is to climb the tree as quickly as possible. The winner is the first player to get all their monkeys onto one of the palm leaves.

Beware the black chimpanzee as he wants all the fruit and will chase the monkeys down when he catches them. The chimpanzee moves when a double is thrown and tries to catch the monkeys.

Contents
1 Surface Area.
11 Red Bulb Covers.
11 Yellow Bulb Covers.
1 White Bulb Cover.
1 Question/Answer Booklet.
Rules Are Printed on Inner Box Lid.

An electric (battery operated) quiz game, based on the early days of a BBC game show with this name. The questions are from General Knowledge categories.

The board shows various routes to the goal. The shorter the route taken means harder questions but you save a lot of time.Quiz Ball Game

The Game features 500 Questions - With real flashing lights and a buzzer noise!

Boardgame released by Denys Fisher in the seventies as part of the Comic Action Heroes line of toys. 
It's an official DC licensed version, and includes the heroes Superman, Batman, Robin and Shazam against the villains Joker, Riddler, Mr Freeze and the Penguin.
It's a fairly basic roll and move game, where the object is to reach the top of the 3-d cityscape that clips onto the board, but the playes also control the movement of the villains to hinder your opponents progress.

Contents
1 Game Board.
1 Dice.
1 Playing Piece Car.
3 Playing Piece Motorcycles.
1 Rules Sheet.

Simple die rolling game. From the start, you move round the track, obeying instructions on special squares. The first player to cross the finish line, wins.

Published in a limited edition, plastic leather pack to celebrate the 10th anniversary of dV Giochi, Dieci is a trick-taking game with illustrations taken from many dV Giochi titles. The players are "Radiatov", a race of aliens who want to collect artwork from particular games.

To start the game, each player receives ten cards (with some cards removed for fewer than six players and a smaller hand size for 7-8 players) as well as a secret goal card. Cards come in five suits valued from 2 to A. The top card of the remaining deck is revealed to show a trump suit, and three of the 30 characters are laid face-up.

The trick-taking in Dieci is fairly standard: One player leads a card, with everyone else following suit if possible and throwing off (or playing trump) if not possible. The highest trump card claims all cards in the trick; if no trump was played, then the highest card regardless of suit wins the trick. The player claiming the trick must then claim one face-up character card bearing a suit played in that trick; if no such character is face-up, the player claims the top character card from the deck. Going clockwise, each player then claims a remaining character card or passes; once everyone has passed or all characters have been claimed, the next trick begins.

Once the character deck runs out, the game ends. Players score:


    One point for each card claimed.
    A variable number of points (0-20) depending on how many characters they took that are shown on their secret goal card.
    Their lowest-valued character card in each of the five suits. For each other character in a suit, they lose points equal to that character's value.


The player with the highest score wins.

In July 1809 the largest British expeditionary force ever assembled weighed anchor off the Kent coast and sailed for the island of Walcheren in the Scheldt estuary.
The map of Walcheren 1809 represents the Southern part of the Walcheren Island and the fortress of Flushing (Flessingue or Vlissiningen), the theatre of the battle. 
 The players have two different tasks. The British player has to march towards Flushing fortress in order to avoid a strong occupation by enemies. In order to do so he risks attrition and diseases. In effects there was fighting with the French, but the worst casualties were inflicted by diseases. Dysentery and other infectious illnesses arising from the unhealthy swampland killed thousands and incapacitated many more, causing the abandonment of the inglorious expedition.
The British lost over 4,000 men to a disease called "Walcheren Fever", thought to be a combination of malaria and typhus.

The French player has two options:
1- attack the British columns try to delay their advance
2- retreat inside Flushing and flood the area nearby (mining the dams)

Victory is assigned to the British player by controlling the fortress of Flushing. The French player wins if  he has the control of Flushing while having eliminated 10 British units. Any other outcome is a draw.

A Chess-like move and capture game played on an 8 x 8 board which includes terrain, which enables ambushes, has swamps to avoid and forts into which retreats may be conducted, but which may also be besieged.

Box says:  Explore the great city of Paris from the comfort of your home.  A strategy-travel game, for 2-6 players.  #7471, 1974 Gameophiles Unlimited, Inc. 16 Pine St., Morristown, NJ 07960.  Patent Pending.

Roll the die and move.  Land on special squares and pick cards that move you to different places like the Louvres Museum or the Eiffel Tower, Arch of Triumph, Church of Sacre Couer etc. Enter the city from Orly Airport, The Palace at Versailles, Longchamps or Colombey. See the needed number of places in the city to win the game.

Objective: collect/gain as many tiles/chips with quality fishes 
as possible
- moving by turns
1. players place their meeples on the board (circle) - youngest one starts 
2. turn a tile (fish is shown)- try to catch it by
3. rolling the dice - move your meeple (forewards or backwards)
4. or move the octopus - to block the loot 
5. pick up the loot - if accessible
6. flip over another tile/fish - later on 2 tiles at once
7. game ends if no tiles are available 
Player with high score (most valuable fishes) wins

An extraordinary game.
The game is played on any reasonable sized table. 2, 4 or 6 players can play.

This must be a forerunner of football games like Subbuteo. But, instead of little footballers that you flick, in this game you where the football boots. The diagram illustrates this rather well. You kick the ball literally with your boot-encased finger.

The rules allow for free kicks, throw-ins and penalties.

There is a warning that your boot fingers must be on the table at all times, so that should be very friendly with six players, three a side!

Players take turns rolling to move around the board where they can buy properties, gain permanent upgrades, defeat monsters and avoid traps, and duel each other for dominance.

Monsters and Traps are on High and Low Level Dungeon cards which players can choose from when they land on a Dungeon tile.  After a successful roll (and associated modifiers), you can win gold pieces.  Unsuccessful rolls reduce your hit points.

Properties can be purchased and upgraded with housing, affecting the amount of rent opponents must pay when they land on your property.  If you collect enough properties of certain types, you can gain control of the castle in that territory. The right to own properties can also be dueled over by rolling against each other using various modifiers.

To win the game, you must be the first player to complete two objectives: gain control of a castle and defeat the dragon.

The game strives to make the 'opoly style genre more fun and engaging. RPG elements, easy to learn mechanics and fast paced gameplay make it simply superior to it's predecessors. It was updated in 2023 for a smoother gameplay experience, and streamlined to be playable in 90 minutes.

The game can found as print-on-demand on The Game Crafter.
https://www.thegamecrafter.com/games/castlecontrol

It is also available for playtesting using TableTop Simulator on the Steam Workshop.

'Flicking through the Ages' is a 2-player dexterity civilization game created as part of the NaGaDeMon contest during the month of November 2011.  Aside from the obvious Through the Ages nod, FttA claims Flicochet, Tumblin Dice, Breakout and the classic carnival game of knocking over milk bottles as its primary pedigree.

FttA aims to deliver the civilization 'feel' to a dexterity game playable in under 30 minutes and assembled from easy to find materials.  It combines five completely different minigames into a timeless struggle for cultural supremacy!  Players balance their actions by using population discs in the following ways:

1. Gather resources by flicking your disc down a platform decreasing in size with increased return for increased risk.
2. Research new technologies by flicking your disc at one of four stacks of available technologies arranged like a breakout game and taking the block you strike.  Once obtained, players need to choose whether or not to add the technology to their list of abilities or to trade in the block to increase their population
3. Declare war on the other player's civilization by flicking your disc at their researched technologies stacked in a pyramid.  Knock your opponent's blocks down to steal population, technology or colonies
4. Vie for colonies by flicking your disc closer to the colony disc than your opponents
5. Construct Wonders of the World by stacking resource cubes on a disc and sliding it along a path symbolizing the shape of the building without letting one fall

NOTES:

Construction of 'Flicking Through the Ages' requires:
1 set of Jenga-style blocks
1 set (2 colors) of 'bakelite'-style backgammon discs or other discs of roughly 1.25" diameter that flick reasonably well and are heavy enough to impact a tower of Jenga blocks enough to fall over
1 set of the rules including the 'colony' and 'technology' sticker sets to be applied (or taped) to the above components

In 8-Bit Invaders, you are defending your home planet from an onslaught of alien invaders. Each turn, you roll six dice and use them to attack the advancing horde; then the aliens march inexorably forward. If you can kill all of the invaders before they land, you win; otherwise, you die.

Designed for the Solitaire Print and Play Contest.

Objective: be the first to get rid of all your cards

1. each player receives 5 cards (randomly) - other cards will be placed in a stack on the back onto the board
2. turn the top card and place it according the illustrated letter on the board
3a. player left to the starting may place a card with a letter, part of the previous placed card
3b. same player may place a new/additional card on the board  if the leading letter is part of previous placed card (3a)
3c. player may continue according above mentioned rule
4. if he/she can't place an additional card next player may 
act in similar way, but if no card can be played a new/additional card must be taken
5. if you empty your hand - you win
golden chip is used to mark the card last played
game was published for two different target groups
children and addults - see editions/images

Quick Overview

Ant Assault is quick and easy to learn card game that puts each player in charge of their own ant nest. They must send parties of ants out to forage, all the while defending themselves and their nest from assault by the other players.

Details
 Players can experiment with many types of ant, including scouts who root out the enemy and find new resources, honey pot ants who store food, soldier ants who fight, and the dreaded bullet ants who lead assaults.
 Enter the world of an ant nest, and dominate the garden!

Objective: be the first to arrive at your tent with all 4 parts of a golden mask 
players are acting by turns, using 2 dice
1 die has to be used for your meeple, the other to move a lion
players dig for gold - better: parts of a mask
each part buried four times - but you must find 4 matching parts
you may dug, block (with lions), steal whatever brings you closer to the goal to leave the others behind...

In the summer of 1945 the United States had a firm grasp of the Pacific Theater. Japans once mighty fleet was all but shattered and unable to support any garrisoned island against an U.S. attack. With Iwo Jima taken earlier in the year the U.S. had an island to land damaged bombers that were hitting the mainland island. To launch an invasion of the main island of Japan the U.S. would need a bigger stepping stone to launch from; Okinawa was the answer.

This is a 2 player game set on the island of Okinawa and surrounding waters that recreates the battle between U.S. and Japanese forces during World War 2. The basic rules follow the concepts laid out in Axis & Allies, but combat resolution has been modified to a D12 system. The game can be played to 10 turns or 20 depending on the length of time desired; and victory is determined by the number of airbases held or carriers destroyed. The map is divided into areas that are controlled by the players' armies represented by the plastic Axis & Allies pieces.

The rules incorporate a number of new features to the Axis & Allies style of play including terrain effects, country specific units, and all new unit types including flame tanks and LCMs.

The young witches Bibi, Schubia, Flauipaui and Arkadia need to pass their exams at the end of the year.

Krötenhopsen again tests dexterity. You have one try per toad to snip it into the pond with yor finger. Each toad ending up in the pond, totally or in part, scores 1 point. If the toad touches the water lily, the score is 2 points. The player with the majority of points after 3 rounds wins the game.

The young witches Bibi, Schubia, Flauipaui and Arkadia need to pass their exams at the end of the year.

Hexwissen tests knowledge. The referee poses the questions and gives three answers - the first player to call out the correct answer receives the card.  The first player who collects four cards wins the game.

There are 16 characters from the stories of the little king Macius in this game. Each character consists of four cards (hat, head, belly and legs). The players roll the dice and try to collect all cards and whoever has the most complete figures at the end of the game wins.

Invented by a Korean dad who wanted to help his kids learn how to master and conquer math. Throughout the game, you simply add up 3 tiles to make a sum of "10," 3 and 4 tiles to make a sum of "20." Each color is played separately and the black tiles are joker tiles. The goal of the game is to get rid of your tiles first!

Minions brings the classic web-based style game called 'Tower Defense' to your table top. Two criminal masterminds send waves of minions to destroy the enemy HQ. To keep the minions away, each player deploys a variety of towers to eliminate those pesky minions. The first player to sneak three minions through their enemy's defensive perimeter succeeds in destroying the enemy HQ and winning the game.

Minions uses a variable map system allowing different paths each time you play. Machine Guns, Cannons, Missiles, and Death Rays abound to frustrate the Minions' attempts at destruction.

Top Promoter is a new card game for 3-5 players in which players try to make more money than their opponents. By putting their fighters in the best position for the big payday, players increase their chances of victory!

Each player has his own deck of 15 fighters and five action cards. Each round, players simultaneously play a fighter face-down, then reveal them at the same time. These cards get played into locations that are in the center of the table following certain rules. Once a location has three fights, the fights are resolved through dice.

Each fighter has a number of dice he rolls that can be modified with action cards or by fighting in his home location. The number of dice can range from 1-7 dice, and whoever rolls the single highest die wins! However, some fighters have a signature move that will guarantee victory!

Top Promoter is a light game that inspires trash talking and cheering as the underdog takes down the favorite!

Viva la ResistANTS! is an abstract boardgame. Main game mechanics includes area controll, set collection and 'press your luck'. It combines American and European styles of boardgaming design. The game has a unique setting. The forces of Resistance of Ants led by the mysterious Serg Ant try to help the civilians survive under the occupation of enemy forces, who perfidiously attacked the peaceful republic of ants. Now you must fight for your freedom. Let's say together: Viva la ResistANTS!

Each player has a detachment of 10 ants. Each turn the player can send 2 of them to the field to participate in a special mission or withdraw 1-3 of them. At the start of the game the playfield is generated randomly. If 1 or more ants get status missing in action, players should shuffle the tiles of the playfield and generate it randomly again. Other ants return to players. The ants get status missing in action if a card from alert deck with the appropriate colour is revealed for the second time. One card from alert deck is revealed every time each player takes a turn. If the same colour is revealed for the third time the alert deck must be shuffled. If it must be shuffled for the second time, the game is over. The player who gets more victory points becomes a winner. In case of a tie, the winner is the player who retained more ants.

A fast and fun party game based on questions and dexterity!

A good materials inside the box. You must Slam the plastic hammers on a category to answer at the questions!
During each round the reader in turn must take an Action card and follow what it says: for example, you must read the question and talk with a "french accent" or cover an eye with your hand.
Moreover, the player reads the question without reading the category; who knows the answer must slam the hammer on a board in the space of the correct category!

A fast party game from 3 to 24 players!

Based on a TV Quiz Show aired in Italy.

There are more than 300 different cards with a transformed or masked image that represents a famous person, an animal, an object, a monument, a painting or a sculpture.

The active player must to recognize the subject of the pic and gain points.

Fun little game, with 4 different variants, based on good observation and quick thinking.
In Lumacorsa, a family card game about snail-racing, players have to bet on the snails involved in the race. A player can alter the speed of the snails by playing cards from his hand.

Objective: collect as many quality coconuts as possible
- moving by turns -
1. Preparation of the game - place all coconut tiles face down (good and bad) on dedicated fields
2. roll the die and move - if the die shows the tiger move back to your starting place
3. if you step on a coconut - pick it up and check 
4. if you land on an opponent's meeple - steal a coconut and put her/him in the middle of the board (palm tree)
5. if there are only 4 or less coconuts on the board use a rolled '4' to move AND steal a coconut from a player

Die Spielidee: 2 - 4 Affen rasen auf die Lichtung und jagen nach Kokosnüssen. Dabei passiert eine ganze Menge. Der Tiger ist auch unterwegs und den mögen die Affen nicht. Wer zum Schluss die meisten Kokosnüsse (geklaut) hat, ist nicht unbedingt Sieger, denn es gibt auch faule Nüsse.

Objective: be the first to reach the finish line
- moving by turns -
1. place the meeples on the starting position
2. turn the spinner and draw a question card
3. there is one minute left to find an appropriate answer - starting with the letter the spinner is pointing on
4. if you fail roll the die - if the number matches with correspondent letter number you may move, too
5. if spinner points at a symbol act as described

You are a solitary hero fighting to survive in a world once afflicted by ancient wars between Orcs, Elves, Humans and Angels and other Races (included in the expansions Cripta, Covo, Alchimista).

It does not matter if you are a Mage, a Paladin or a Warrior (or another Class contained in Cripta, Covo, Alchimista expansions); all you have to do is to get the most powerful equipment you can find, such as handcrafted swords and shields, spells or what remains of the fire guns and hi-tech weapons produced by a now-gone civilisation.

Defend yourself and defeat your opponents. Are you ready to fight?

Warage is the ultimate turn-based strategic card game: role play, strategy and deck building merged all together for endless adventures.

Objective: collect as many precious treasurers as possible & try to block other players
- moving by turns -
1. shuffle treasure cards and put 3 of them upside down on the board - place all the track tiles,too
2. roll the die - move your meeple into direction of a treasure
3. at the end of your turn you may turn a track tile at 90° degree to the left or right (blocking or preparing your route)
4. if you roll a 'wand' you may exchange one of your treasures for another player's one (different values)
5. if all treasures a collected count up the values printed on the tile
